title: How to Knit an Increase Stitch

steps.title: Use knit front and back when you don’t mind leaving a bump.
steps.content: Use knit front and back when you don’t mind leaving a bump. Knitting front and back is an easy way to increase. However, increasing this way leaves a visible bump in your knitting, so it is not ideal for all projects. [1] X Research source For example, you might use this method of increasing when you are using a textured stitch, such as the garter stitch. It is also fine to use when the area with the increases will be hidden, such as on the underside of a sleeve.

steps.title: Knit the stitch
steps.content: Knit the stitch without letting the old stitch slip off. Push the right-hand needle into the front of the stitch on the left-hand needle and loop the yarn over the end of the needle. [2] X Research source Then, pull the yarn through, but do not allow the old stitch to slip off the needle yet. [3] X Research source If you are purling this row, then purl this first stitch without letting the old stitch slip off.

steps.title: Insert the right-hand needle into the back of the same stitch and knit.
steps.content: Insert the right-hand needle into the back of the same stitch and knit. Wrap the yarn wound the end of the needle after inserting it into the stitch. Then, pull through to complete the stitch. Let the old stitch slip off the end of the needle at this point. [4] X Research source If you are purling, then you can purl into this stitch instead.

steps.title: Insert the left-hand needle under the strand between stitches.
steps.content: Insert the left-hand needle under the strand between stitches. There should be a visible strand between the 2 stitches on the right-hand and left-hand needles. Locate this strand and use the tip of the left-hand needle to lift it up. [5] X Research source You may need to separate the stitches with your fingers to find the strand.

steps.title: Use your fingers to twist the strand and put it back on the needle.
steps.content: Use your fingers to twist the strand and put it back on the needle. Grasp the strand on the left-hand needle with your index finger and thumb and slip it off the needle. Then, twist it 1 time and slide it back onto the needle in this twisted position. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Knit into the new loop as usual to make a stitch.
steps.content: Knit into the new loop as usual to make a stitch. Insert the right-hand needle into the loop you just twisted, and yarn over the end of the needle. Then, pull this loop through the twisted loop to create a new stitch. [7] X Research source If you need to purl this stitch, then you can purl into the stitch as you normally would. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Work the stitch in the back as well if you need to make 2.
steps.content: Work the stitch in the back as well if you need to make 2. If you need to make 2 stitches out of the twisted loop, don’t let the loop slide off of your needle after you knit into it. Instead, knit into the back of the loop, and then let the loop slide off. [9] X Research source If you are purling, purl into the back of the stitch after purling into the front of the stitch.

steps.title: Knit a stitch as you normally would.
steps.content: Knit a stitch as you normally would. Insert the right-hand needle into the stitch going from front to back. Then, loop the yarn over the end of the needle and pull it through to create a new stitch. [10] X Research source If you are on a purl stitch or row, then purl the stitch instead.

steps.title: Bring the working yarn to the front of your work.
steps.content: Bring the working yarn to the front of your work. Grasp the strand of working yarn and bring it up and over your work. The yarn should be hanging down in front of your knitting as if you were going to purl. [11] X Research source If you are purling, bring the yarn to the back as if to knit.

steps.title: Wrap the yarn over the top of your right-hand knitting needle and knit.
steps.content: Wrap the yarn over the top of your right-hand knitting needle and knit. Lift the strand up and over the right-hand needle before knitting the next stitch. Then, knit the stitch as usual. [12] X Research source If you are purling, wrap the yarn under the right-hand needle and then purl.
